pros: Good Pay Good Management Good Location

pros: Competitive pay Very busy with acute pt- great for learning Easy to talk to residents and ask questions Decent Benifits

pros: Coworkers on the unit are supportive

review_title: There’s a reason for very quick turnover at this hospital
pros: Most of the people are friendly and helpful The CEO has tried to create a culture of caring for each other like family Free parking $5 parking / day right across the street, by the church
cons: They don’t tell potential employees that the “paid holidays” actually mean you will be using accrued PTO to pay yourself for the holidays Very rapid turnover of staff leading to resentment in people precepting the new hires - they then make the new hires feel unwelcome Upper management (the one I reported to) was very unprofessional and created a hostile work environment for the person I replaced; when that person left, the same thing was done to me. No one wants to talk to HR because of retaliation, which HR says they will investigate. I will update this review if I ever hear back from them. New hires earn more than the current staff, creating employee dissatisfaction.

pros: We are a union Pay is decent
cons: Our contract is currently up and under review, they want to take our health insurance. We are understaffed, underplayed and under appreciated for the work that is put in. Nurses have PTSD from Covid and understaffed, Dr’s are being worked passed exhaustion (fainting at work). Housekeeping is unable to keep up with the demand of the hospital all while being underpaid.

pros: benefits, pay, flexibility, growth, development
cons: metric heavy, profit over patients, frontline staffds input

pros: Pay Opportunity for OT High acuity/will learn a lot of skills

review_title: Good pay, decent benefits, tone deaf management
pros:
Amazing learning opportunities
Competitive pay
New grad preceptorship
ER nurses and staff overall are team oriented, supportive of new grads, hardworking, kind and knowledgeable
cons:
Management is a revolving door
Some CNCs are not supportive/receptive to new grads
The learning curve is very steep
Patient acuity is often too high to stay in ratio
Equipment is often broken, unavailable
Preceptorship requires a lot of time to work on projects or show up to classes that feel unnecessary and create frustration and burnout
MDs, especially admitting, can be rude, are often unavailable, and are never held to the same standards as nursing staff.

review_title: Potentially a great job, but needs better management.
pros:
- Pay is good. 
- Paid benefits as a FT employee. 
- Character building position.
cons:
- Manager micromanages and entertains department drama. 
- Equipment is always failing/broken. 
- Bullying and harassment is overlooked/dismissed.
- Don’t follow policies as far as holiday time off, etc. 
- Management is very one sided, so if you ever get in trouble by girls with more seniority, good luck.
- When everyone is on LOA/calling off you’ll be expected to meet demands on the spot; mandatory overtime, working longer shifts, picking up more shifts, etc.

review_title: If you can work here you can work anywhere

pros: Great staff once you get to know people
cons: Nurses stay getting caught being intimate with other staff and doctors, the hospital only cares about making money, all the nurses are over worked so they take there anger out on others yet expect others to respect them, management is a joke, very unsafe hospital, some armed guards are wanna be cops who take the fact that they are armed to the head and make the rest of us look bad, doctors and nurses act as if they are our boss when we try to enforce the rules and regulations that we are told to enforce, lets not even speak about the daily fire hazards in this hospital, this hospital is over crowded but thats because they want the money, patient care on a scale from 1-10 is a 2, hippa violations left and right, nurses have been caught abusing patients, nurses and techs have been caught stealing pain medication, when the pandemic hit friends told me that staff where stealing medical equipment such as mask, wipes, respirators, gloves, disinfectant, scrubs. This place is more like a county hospital with all the issues. You might get robbed if you walk to your car at night cause security is busy making out at the top of the parking structure or in a on call room. Its bad

pros: It is a good place to work
cons: No cons I have in mind

pros: Good management, good benefits, a lot of good staff
cons: Hospital does not look out for employees interest

pros:
- Great Health Benefits: Free HMO Medical, Cheap Dental & Vision
- Awesome Cafeteria.  Great Food w/ constant new menu options.  30% employee discount
- Free Parking and Nearby
- Rare Concierge Service that will run errands for you while you work. Cheap Admission Tickets to movies, theme parks, etc.
- Employees who have been there for many years have a great heart and are very descent people. They are usually kind,friendly and helpful. It's those brand new people in higher management  that you have to be careful with.
cons:
- No work life balance, worked almost all weekends and very late evenings. Very uncommon schedule for non-managerial accounting positions. No time for anything but work. Not a good office for people with family.
- PTO includes holidays and sick time - this means you won't get paid for holidays until you have been there a few months and you probably won't want to take sick time because that will cut into your vacation time
- Deceptive Job Posting. Beware of short job posting details, doesn't describe half the actual work or the workload. Won't find out until you're already working. Mine didn't mention payroll once, and I ended up being responsible for the review and accuracy of +1,900 employees' payroll.
- Very cutthroat & High Turnover. Many senior management or tenured employees termed or demoted often, little notice. I printed termination checks everyday.
- Budget cuts as bad as elsewhere. Bring your own coffee, water, cups, etc..or stop by cafeteria

review_title: The pay is great but you work hard for it.

review_title: I'm a new grad and this is my first job, overall I feel supported by my co-workers & union.
pros: It's a good learning environment, good salary & benefits, best upon request and the RN union. I like working with my co-workers, we're like family. the work is hard but very satisfying. Computer charting needs to be less confusing, more organized. I'd like to spend more time with my patients than on the computer.
cons:
Parking! The parking structure really isn't very safe. I pay for parking @ the church and that doesn't seem fair to have to pay for parking to go to work and be safe.
Security, isn't very helpful.

review_title: Pay is great, but you work for it, you seriously work for it.
pros: The pay is excellent (but you will go through hell making it) and the benefits are good. Good retirement and the HMO has no payroll deduction.
cons: Poor teamwork, few support staff, frequently out of ratio. Unfortunately, whatever management may want to do to improve the work environment, corporate turns around and says "no." Many nurses are burned out and call offs are a common occurrence because the staff is tired of being worked to exhaustion. Staff frequently get no lunch relief or late lunch relief (starts shift at 7, no breaks until after 3). I came here for the pay increase, but ultimately I wish I hadn't. I would have been happier with friendlier coworkers and better teamwork at my last hospital. The union is also not very supportive.

pros: Staff is friendly. Parking is convenient. One free meal per shift.
cons: Unorganized, inefficient, and chaotic work environment. Nurses are overloaded with responsibility and are pushed to meet unrealistic expectations. Patient care seems to come last in what is important to the overall expectation of nurses. The charting system is by far the most out of date, inefficient and time consuming. I spend more time on the computer than I did with my patients. Also, if you do not clock out by a certain time, even if you are putting patients first, management will blame the nurse for not having time management. I saw most nurses cut corners just to clock out in time. Shift change if chaotic, as everyone rushes through SBAR to clock out on time. If you work nights, they will schedule you every other night, so no time to recover. Employees were always getting sick and working sick, as they are run down. Poor equipment. Poor management. Poor staffing. All in all an absolute nightmare.

pros:
The pay is great
The people I work with are wonderful
My manager is very available and friendly
Charge Nurses are great
cons:
The patient load on the Med/Surg Chronic Care unit is very heavy
They do not follow Patient/Nurse ratio laws
Sometimes Tele Nurses who are only supposed to have 4 pts at the most will get 5
Outdated system of charting
Poor upper class management

review_title: The internal environment has lost the love. Changes have caused a negative work environments.
pros: EXCELLENT benefits available.  Good food served in cafeteria.  A large number of volunteers helping.
cons: Employees have a cut-throat attitude due to being micro-managed, additional duties and responsibilities, and lack of respect from management.  This hospital is extremely top-heavy with Managers and Senior Management employees.  You have to be accepted by certain employees to survive...there are very click-ie groups composed of employees protected by management.

pros: Great opportunity for stable employment.   Benefits are good.  The Chief Executive Officer is approachable.  Senior team is engaged.  Down to earth leadership.
cons: It's difficult to move up in the organization.  No training for administrative positions.  No administrative, COO internship opportunity.  Still trying to overcome a history of silos.

pros: If you are in a management position you get bonuses based on production, its a great deal. Most of the managers will work together to increase each others production numbers, they will even falsify records and lie to patients and staff.
cons: Being a non-management staff member or a patient your concerns and or healthcare come second to profit.
